name: The OHF Revolution
description: After having succeeded in gathering a good number of loyal officers, Mustafa Kemal Pasha overthrew the liberal government responsible for the defeat, which was equally hated by him and the army. Now the Gazi can finally implement his long overdue reforms to save the Empire without fear of opposition.

name: Ban Political Parties
description: In order to achieve unopposed reform of the Empire, we need to take a temporary but authoritarian measure. By banishing the political parties responsible our defeat at the hands of the Cairo Pact, we ensure that our reforms will have a free hand.

name: Suspend the Assembly
description: The assembly caused the fall of our government in 1936, so we must suspend it until a stable regime is established. Mustafa Kemal Pasha's ambitions are to establish a democracy, so we can trust him in his aspirations.

name: Eliminate the Resistance
description: Many remnants of decentralist government remain in the Anatolian hinterland. Despite our almost perfect control of the cities thanks to the support of the local garrisons, many administrations and institutions remain in liberal hands. We must go through the motions of eliminating the resistance once and for all.

name: Lift the State of Emergency
description: Now that the country seems to have returned to calm and the subversive elements have been eliminated, we can reestablish the assembly with some changes to the voting system for the election of deputies and their importance in preventing legislation from being passed.

name: Protect the National Economy
description: We can deal with the crisis that has hit our country in defeat by protecting it from foreign capital and refocusing the Turkish economy on itself. By launching an austerity policy to control our inflation, we can turn the economy around. For this, we will increase the tax pressure on foreign capital and raise the interest rates of our banks.

name: New Laws on Foreign Economy
description: We need to put in place new foreign trade laws to protect our domestic economy even more. To this end, we will seek to protect our local producers by law against the overwhelming competition from the international market.

name: Centralise Anatolian Vilayets
description: We can finally centralise the vilayets by installing more loyal administrators and by increasing the power of the central government. This will allow us to better push through our future reforms.

name: Nationalise Ottoman Banks
description: Many of our national banks are owned by foreign capital, which puts them in subjective situations regarding our investment requests for projects that would be contrary to foreign economic interests. By buying back large shares or simply by pushing them to withdraw their capital, our banks will truly serve the Empire and not foreigners.

name: Begin a Five-Year Plan
description: We need to move from a market-based to a planning-based economic policy. First of all, the state must decide on the economic plan that will define the next five years. The first objective of this five-year plan should be to restore the Turkish economy so that it will able to face future events.

name: Kemal's Will
description: The man who saved Anatolia, our pasha, is dead. It is the duty of Ismet Resit, Kemal's dearest friend, to honour his will. The government will now work to build a new, modern nation, inspired by the will of the Gazi. However, the opposition is strong and the empire in disarray. Will Ismet, the new strong man of the country, be able to handle the task that is before him?

name: An Economic Revolution
description: To follow the Kemal's ideals, his friend Ismet decided to continue the idea of the five-year plan by adding a slight civil touch, which according to him is essential. Although some generals would have preferred the plan to focus on the reconstruction of the military industry, Ismet follows the logic of peace desired by the Gazi.

name: Kemalist Principles
description: Here are the six principles, as they were defined by Mustafa Kemal: §gRepublicanism§!, the creation of a democratic republic. §gNationalism§!, safeguarding the integrity of the nation. §gPopulism§!, the ownership of sovereignty and governance by the people. §gRevolutionism§!, the importance of continuous progress towards civilisation. §gSecularism§!, 'emancipation from the dungeon of thought'. Finally, §gStatism§!, the predominance of the state in the economy.

name: Separation of State and Church
description: The first mandatory step of the Kemalist reforms was the separation of church and state. This idea dates back to the Enlightenment and has been implemented in a few states such as France. This principle of secularism in law establishes the religious neutrality of the state. In the Ottoman Empire, this issue was all the more delicate, as the head of state was also the head of Islam.

name: The Sultanate and the Republic
description: The most important point in Kemal's will is the notion of "Republic." The Gazi refers many times to his desire to transform Turkey into a democracy, but above all into a republic, and to overthrow the monarchical system which he considered corrupt and backward. However, this question remains open to debate, even if many politicians agree with it, as the sultan's influence on politics has already been erased for almost forty years now.

name: Personality Cult
description: It is time to give Ismet Reşit a real place. Although he was not the initiator of the Kemalist reforms, he is the one who is responsible for implementing them. As the successor of the Gazi, he is himself a general with great talent and a determined politician. The 'Second Man' of the nation intends to lead it through the century.

name: Question of Ostentatious Signs
description: A Turk is recognisable to any European. Our religion leads us to wear recognisable signs, the fez or turban for men and the hijab or burqa for women. However, these uncomfortable clothes should no longer be an obligation. Let men wear hats to protect themselves from the sun or simply to look like modern men, and let women free their hair and undress to avoid the imposition of a suffocating veil. But are the people and the institutions ready for this reform?

name: Protectionism
description: Rather than moving towards simple autarky, let's leave a minimal place for the market and for the most necessary commodities. For this, we can introduce standards and quotas on all imports and taxes on products that are too competitive for our local producers.

name: Tariffs on Foreign Goods
description: Finally, we can establish a permanent reform of taxes on foreign products. In addition, foreign companies that want to buy Turkish products will have to pay a fee. With a smaller nation we need to conserve resources.

name: Turkish State Railways
description: Kemal was particularly fond of certain tools such as the telegraph or the train. For him, the latter made it possible to improve not only physical mobility in the country but also intellectual mobility by allowing the dissemination of ideas and the improvement of living conditions.

name: Undermine Free Trade
description: Still in a protectionist logic, it is time for the nation and its companies to focus on themselves and not on the lure of world trade. For this, the implementation of laws targeting our producers will be essential.

name: Nationalisation Dilemma
description: The question of our economic inclination has long been discussed and Kemal did not elaborate on the subject. An important part of the party thinks that if the Gazi wanted the establishment of a democratic republic based on European principles then this republic would have to accept to remain in a liberal economic mode. However, a minority wing of the OHF party called 'Kadro' believes that it is necessary to nationalise most of the economy for the nation's safety.

name: Classless Society
description: The Kadroist party took power. During the nationalisation issue, the party voted to nationalise the majority of goods and means of production useful to the state. Following the party crisis, most of the deputies took refuge in the Kadroist wing. Mehmet Recep Pasha, an extremist close to Kemal, declared Turkish society to be free of social struggle and called for the union of the 'Classless society'.

name: Turkish Man Myth
description: The Kadro paper, in its desire to unify the Turkish people, sometimes unaware of their unity, created a model Turkish man. Some people think they mean Mustafa Kemal or even Mehmet Recep Peker. In any case, their notion of the Turkish man is by definition the physical power for work and war but also the intellectual power, will and determination of the Turkish people.

name: Turkish Solidarism
description: The idea of Turkish solidarism is said to come from the sociology of Emile Durkheim and his French solidarism. Regardless of its origin, it consists of the social accountability of each individual. A child is indebted to all his peers for what they have given him, be that education, values or knowledge. Thus, the Kadro movement bases its interpretation of society from a Marxist-Materialist point of view on the very principle of human relationships in order to analyse history.

name: Urban Rural Equality
description: Speaking of a classless society in reality, the only structural difference in the Turkish population is where they live, which greatly affects their aspirations, income and living conditions. They separate the urban and rural class, the latter being greatly divided. However, they call for the establishment of reforms to improve life in the countryside and achieve equality between these two populations.

name: Social Nationalism
description: The social nationalism theorised by Aydemir consists in the total elimination of all forms of class dictatorship, whether proletarian or bourgeois. The term social exemplifies the socio-economic reforms that the party must implement, connected to the word national, which symbolises the Turkish revolution of the nation and the nationally integrated economy.

name: Create a Central Bank
description: The Turkish central bank will make it possible to fix the interest rates of the banks and thus to regulate monetary creation but also to protect the state in the event of a crisis in the international markets. Thanks to the law of supply and demand and its control over the banks within our borders we will be able to reduce the high inflation rate in Turkey.

name: Subsidise Turkish Textile Companies
description: By offering to subsidise textile companies in the Constantinople and Bursa regions, we will improve our comparative advantages, which will in turn increase both our growth and exports. We are limiting foreign competition, but for this we need to improve our own production systems.

name: Waive the Ottoman Debts
description: Since the 19th century, the Empire has incurred a significant amount of debt, especially to European banks and institutions. Nevertheless, we are now a new nation with a new political system and soon a new identity, and it is out of the question that we pay for the mistakes of past Sultans, even if refusing to pay off this debt would degrade our image from an international point of view.

name: The Iraqi Question
description: Currently, we stand alone and isolated among the countries of the Middle East. While many of our neighbouring nations still hold a grudge against us, the newborn state of Iraq is different and has a relatively friendly attitude towards us, mainly because the region of Iraq was thoroughly developed and cared about by the Porte. Maybe we should try to find some new friends in the lands of Mesopotamia.

name: Revenge against the Greeks
description: Exploiting our moment of weakness, the Greek bastards have decided to invade the heart of our nation, arguing that it is rightful Greek territory. Now that we have regained some of our strength, we can send them an ultimatum: either they restore our control over the region, or they will be utterly destroyed by our military might. Hopefully they will be wise enough to realise the hopelessness of their situation.

name: The Status of Iskenderun
description: The region of Iskenderun has always been a melting pot of Arab and Turkish people, which was enough of a justification for Syria to take the region from us after our defeat in the Desert War. However, seeing as there are still many Turks living in the area, this is something we simply cannot accept. It is time to undermine Syria's influence over the region and to remind the people living there of their allegiance to [ROOT.Capital.GetCapitalVictoryPointName].

name: A New National Army
description: The Ottoman army must be transformed into an army composed of Turks. While the army of the Ottoman Empire was composed of conscripts from all over the Empire, our new army should solely be composed of brave Turks. Moreover, our new army will no longer have to defend vast stretches of desert. Instead, it will be able to modernise itself and consider the offensive again.

name: Modern Soldiers
description: Modern Turkish soldiers have to adapt to the harsh conditions of today's mobile and world wars. The wars stretch on fronts from Siberia to the African deserts, but also use modern technologies such as tanks - the new steel monsters.

name: Extend Armoured Research Budget
description: We should create a new budget share in the army to develop research on armour. The new means of locomotion and destruction are often very expensive to produce. By improving our research drastically, we could reduce the production cost of our tanks.

name: Status of the High Command
description: The question of the high command still remains unsolved. Indeed, ever since the complete takeover by the OHF, a significant number of members of the high command have become increasingly attached to politics. By creating a law on the status of the high command, by separating it from the government, and by preventing active militarymen from exercising a political career, we will hopefully be able to reduce our army's influence on our nation's political scene.

name: Redirect our Naval Project
description: The navy is also a weapon that must be relied upon and developed in order to compensate for the loss of our ports in the Middle East. New shipyards based in Smyrna would allow us to design and construct modern vessels.

name: Learn from the Desert War
description: Our defeat against the Cairo Pact was disastrous. We must learn from it, and prepare to take our revenge, not as the Ottoman Empire but as the Turkish people. Moreover, this learning will not only serve us against the Arabs but also help us defend our nation against other threats.

name: Prepare for the Next War
description: Now that our defeat is understood, we must focus on the success of our next campaigns. Especially sincem with diplomatic relations broken down all over Europe, it will be impossible for us to remain neutral without having to defend ourselves.

name: Our Future in the Skies
description: Air warfare is one of the engines of modern warfare, allowing us to gain information, cover battalions on the ground or bomb strategic points. We must prepare for our future in the skies.

name: Popular Sovereignty and Civic Independence
description: Civic independence or popular sovereignty is the confrontation between many centuries of Muslim and institutional traditions. This stage is marked in particular by the abolition of the Millet system and the end of the autonomies relating to the different religions as well as the hierarchy of the Ulema and the Sheikh al-Islam.

name: Unification and Co-education
description: The Unification and Co-education decree, one of the most emblematic decrees of the OHF government, consists first of all of the creation of a public education system, the restriction of religious schools that had become private, and above all the training of imams by the state in order to avoid extremist currents. Co-education or education for girls allowed the nation's women to have access to school.

name: The Turkish Civil Code
description: The Turkish civil code will be based on the Swiss civil code, the most modern of its time, according to a committee formed for the purpose. The main advances include the status of women in marriage and a total ban on polygamy, which shall no longer be practiced. This will be the beginning of complete equality in Turkey.

name: Women's Rights
description: Women's rights must now extend to politics in order to achieve full equality in the nation. In addition, women's rights and feminist organisations must develop with the support of the government and the party. These can now be elected as well. However, male domestic dominance is not yet resolved.

name: The Question of Family Names
description: Surnames do not exist among Turks. All have a first name and often also a nickname, which may be a title, or are called by their father's first name. This reform will aim to westernise the country by making every citizen choose a name in order to become completely unique. However, each name must have a Turkish origin.

name: Abolition of the Ottoman Titles
description: Now that the question of names has been raised, titles must be abolished or at least their importance and hierarchical connotations reduced. These titles are only a reflection of a discriminatory and feudal system that we want to abolish.

name: A Caliphate Alone
description: The final question, the one that every government politician dreads: the abolition of the Caliphate. As Kemal wrote in black and white in the last line of his political testament: the Caliphate must be abolished. However, the measure is not established by a simple sentence. Many politicians would stop supporting the government if this step were to be taken. It would mark the closing of the Ottoman book.

name: Western Calendar and Units System
description: The European metric and time system is not the same as ours. We still give a lot of importance to the Muslim calendar and its metric system, despite the fact that many institutions have already disowned it.

name: Turkish Language Comittee
description: The reform of the alphabet can finally be established. This question had been on the minds of many reformers since the Tanzimat era, but only Kemal appeared to be a real advocate. This would both modernise the nation and bring it together culturally. As the Latin alphabet has only about 30 characters, it would also improve literacy in the country.

name: Turkic History
description: We need to move away from the simple image of the Ottoman Empire linked to Islam. The Turkish nation was not born during the creation of the religion - it was born much earlier. The first Turkish nations date, according to many historians, from the nomadic people of the Asian plains, in Siberia or China, who came down to Europe through Central Asia and Russia. Let us adopt this glorious image of the Turkish warrior people.

name: State Secularism
description: State secularism is the absolute step that Kemal wanted to achieve, no longer simply separating religion and politics but above all applying secularism as a watchword for the whole nation. An end to religious obscurantism, as Kemal wrote: 'Superstition must go. Let them worship as they will, every man can follow his own conscience provided it does not interfere with sane reason or bid him act against the liberty of his fellow men.'

name: Retrospection on our Identity
description: Now that the reforms have been completed, we can take stock of the Turkish identity that has been achieved in such a short time, proving the power of our people. If the reforms have been followed, then Kemal's will promises a great future for our nation.

name: Seize Minorities Monopolies
description: Since the tanzimats and the Millet system, many minorities, especially Christians, had monopolies on many sectors, both industrial and banking. Thus, due to different laws and more lucrative ways of thinking, many companies have come under European influence because their owners were Christian. It is time to have them seized by the state.

name: Dissolve Western Influence
description: The development methods of European and Asian countries have diverged in the capitalist era. In order to achieve independence from the European powers, the foundations of liberalism must be abolished. The theoreticians of the Kadro paper believe, like Lenin, that from a fundamental point of view, the national political independence of each colonised country or almost each colonised country would allow the destruction of the capitalist-imperialist status quo.

name: Mix Western Populisms
description: The Kadro paper is a mixture of European populist and nationalist ideas immersed in a fundamental Marxist logic in the thoughts of the Kadroist authors. However, as Marxism did not allow them to grasp the concept of nation and nationalism, by rejecting racism and imperialism they were able to grant their nationalist principle to this quasi-Marxist ideology. They rejected the national-populist principle of eliminating class through corporatism.

name: Total Welfare State
description: The Kadro paper argued for the elimination of the private sector from decision-making. They believe that the state should be the one who is responsible for the larger part of industrial investment. Therefore, a planned 'etatiste' economic development would restrain the formation of social classes by consciously bringing about an intellectual 'cadre', which would stand independent from any social class and would consider the national interests as the highest priority.

name: Kadroism Movement
description: The main goals of the Kadro movement are to dissolve the influence of the western powers on the political and economic sphere of Turkey, yet to imitate their development with a sense of Turkish identity, and a classless society, where the state is responsible for production and distribution.

name: Permanent Revolutionism
description: Permanent revolutionism, inspired by Lenin's ideas, consists of the belief that the first stage of the revolution was the taking of national political independence. In a second stage - economic independence. Finally, the party must be led by a leading cadre. A man who would dedicate his life to the revolution and the revolutionary party. This man is Mehmed Recep Peker.

name: Create a Turkish Navy
description: Every modern state with a coastline needs a navy to protect its ports, trade routes and coastal cities. It is about time that we start to build one as well.

name: Who Rules the Air Rules on Earth
description: As Kemal understood during the Weltrkrieg, those with air superiority can rule the seas and the land. We should once again adopt this doctrine of fighting on two scales.
